hints.content: Start by understanding the formulas for converting Celsius to Kelvin and Fahrenheit. Remember that Kelvin is simply Celsius plus a constant, while Fahrenheit involves both multiplication and addition.
Make sure to handle the input correctly. The input will be a floating point number representing Celsius, so ensure your function can accept and process this type of data.
When implementing the conversion formulas, pay attention to the precision of the output. The results should be formatted to at least five decimal places to meet the problem's requirements.
Consider how you will store the results of the conversions. An array is specified in the problem statement, so think about how to initialize and populate this array.
Remember that the output should be in a specific order: first Kelvin, then Fahrenheit. This is important for passing the test cases.
Think about edge cases, such as when the input is 0. What should the outputs be for Kelvin and Fahrenheit in this case? This will help ensure your function handles all possible inputs correctly.
You might want to test your function with a variety of Celsius values, including very high values close to the upper limit of 1000. This will help ensure your calculations are robust.
Consider how to format the output to ensure it meets the precision requirement. You might need to use a formatting function to control the number of decimal places.
As you implement the conversion formulas, remember to check the order of operations in your calculations, especially with the Fahrenheit formula, to avoid any errors.
Finally, implement the conversion logic and return the results in the specified array format. Make sure to test your function with the provided examples to verify correctness.

questionNotes: Input: a non-negative floating point number (Celsius) rounded to two decimal places.
Output: an array containing two values: [Kelvin, Fahrenheit].
Precision: Answers within 10^-5 of the actual answer will be accepted.
